With this loan, and your help, she'll begin to turn her desires into a working reality and in turn benefit the happiness of her two small treasures.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Encontramos a la señora Rosmery L. en su salón de belleza Keyla, acabando una muestra de su gran capacidad y habilidad como cosmetóloga, destreza que le ha generado acopiar una gran cantidad de clientas; gracias a este esfuerzo pudo abrir una bodega en casa en la cual pasa el tiempo cuando no está sumergida en las demandas del salón de belleza.El reducido espacio de su salón de belleza, el gran número de clientes y sobretodo las múltiples necesidades de sus hijos, han generado en ella el deseo de modificar el actual local del salón que posee y ampliarlo e implementarlo de una mejor manera, para así seguir brindándoles todo el apoyo y afecto a sus dos menores hijos de 12 y 7 años, de los cuales ella es el único sostén, por ser madre soltera.La realización de estos proyectos demanda una mayor inversión por lo que apela a vuestros generosos corazones solidarios, solicitando un préstamo, con el que empezará a estructurar estos anhelos para seguir trabajando en la realización de la felicidad de sus dos pequeños tesoros. A los cuales usted también puede ayudar recuérdelo.

loans.use: Implementation of a small area for her beauty salon services. (Adecuación e implementación del pequeño espacio de belleza.)

loans.name: Asma

texts.en: I am Asma H. from Lahore, Pakistan. I was married two years ago and I have a daughter who is only five days old. I work with my husband at his bangles store that he has been running for the past six years. Selling bangles is our family business and it is a very profitable business. Eid is around the corner and we need to buy a greater stock of bangles for the store. We need $575 as a loan. I have a savings account where I save money for my child to give her a better future

loans.use: To buy jewellery stock

loans.name: Valle Totora Group

texts.en:
The community bank “Valle Totora” was started 12 months ago. Now they have completed two cycles and have 15 associates. Valle Totera, which is also the community all of the members come from, is a small valley, which is known for agriculture and raising animals; the surrounding land produces vegetables and alfalfa.

In the community bank, the associates have learned to be responsible, punctual, to save, how to invest, how to run a business, how to educate their children, and how to improve their relationships with their husbands. The associates have various businesses such as selling groceries, fruits, vegetables, fish, sodas and other drinks, taxi driving, growing vegetables, and raising animals.

Every associate has a different history they can tell, such as Maria, who started her business one year ago selling a few products. With a loan from her community bank she was able to further develop her business. Today, her store has grown significantly and has many customers.

On the other hand, Ligia Perlita has been selling cebiche, a traditional dish maD. from raw marinated fish, for the past five years. She mentioned that with her loan she would be able to improve her business and prepare more cebiche.

The associates are requesting loans of different sizes; many only need 300, 450, 500, and 900 soles (3 soles = $1) making a total of 7, 050 soles in loans from the community bank.

They will invest these loans in buying roosters, medicinal herbs, oranges, lemons, bananas, and to buy tables and chairs for the “cebicheria”--a café where they serve cebiche.

They plan to use their savings to make sure their children are able to continue school, to increase the capital available for their businesses, and some even to build a house.

Many dream of owning their own house, or having a car to transport their products, and that their children will study and be able to become professionals.

loans.use: invest in and expand their various businesses

loans.name: Bagulete I B Group

texts.en:
Jane M. is a 30-year-old mother of five young children. She makes a living by running a retail store in Kamuli, Uganda, and wishes to buy more merchandise to expand her store. Currently, she earns 20,0000 Ugandan shillings, or 12 U.S. dollars, each week. With the extra profits, she plans on covering basic needs, such as home repairs, clothes, and mandatory school fees.

Jane has applied for a loan of $825 U.S. dollars along with two other women. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Ruth B. hopes to grow her grocery store, and Lovisa K. wants to expand her retail shop. Jane has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to expand a retail store

loans.name: Iyore

texts.en: Iyore O. is married with four children. She is 38 years old. She sells clothing--both wrappers and baby clothes. She is from Edo State, Nigeria, and has been in business since 2005. She needs a loan of $725 to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Leonidas

texts.es:
Producing livestock and making delicious cheeses has become the main and indispensable income for Leonidas’ family. He and his wife come from humble backgrounds, and with a lot of hard work they have been able to stay close to nature and work with it. Following Leonidas’ parents example, he tries to give 100% to everything he does, thereby earning well and improving his family’s financial situation. Now that his kids need more and more financial support for their studies, Leonidas knows he needs more income, and this is why he thought of genetically improving the breed of his animlas so the productivity of milk of each of his calves would improve. Leonidas and his family need your support to move forward.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La producción de ganado y la elaboración de deliciosos quesos se ha convertido en el ingreso económico indispensable de la familia de Leonidas. Él y su querida esposa provienen de familias muy humildes con gran voluntad de trabajo que siempre mantuvo un lazo estrecho con la madre naturaleza y el trabajo en ella.Siguiendo el ejemplo de sus padres don Leonidas trata de poner su mayor esfuerzo a cada actividad que realiza, con el fin de obtener buenos ingresos y mejorar su situación económica familiar.Ahora que sus hijos le van demandando mayores gastos por los estudios que vienen realizando se ve en la necesidad de incrementar más sus ingresos, es por ello que tiene pensado mejorar genéticamente la raza de sus animalitos para aumentar la productividad de leche de cada una de sus tiernas becerritas.Don Leonidas y su familia recurren a vuestro apoyo para salir adelante.

loans.use: Some capital in improve the breed his breed of animal/Inyección de capital para mejorar la raza de sus animalitos.

loans.name: Abu

texts.en: Abu S. is a primary teacher who earns less than $100 a month.  With skills in tie and dye, he started a small business.  He could produce the materials  during weekends and sell to retailers.  The news about the Kiva program reached S. and he approached SMT with a request of a $525 loan to purchase more materials, (ink and caustic soda) to increase the production. S. will repay his installments from his monthly salary.  Abu S. is 30 years old and single.

loans.use: Expansion of his stock of tie and dye business.

loans.name: Enosse Fernando

texts.pt:
Enosse is 41 years old and he is from the province of Inhambane. Currently, he lives in Namaacha, a village in the province of Maputo which borders Swaziland. Enosse is married and is the father of 2 children -- both are students, the oldest is 13 years old and the youngest is 10 years old. Enosse lives in his own home with his wife, children, a cousin and a nephew. In 1987, he left the province of Inhambe for Maputo to look for work. There, he worked for a company that closed down after two years. Six months later another investor decided to reopen the company and rehired some of the previous employees including Enosse. He took the job because at that time he still had not found employment anywhere else. This business also failed after three years but this time the employees received a severance reward payment. With this reward money Enosse purchased a vehicle and started a chicken raising business. For four years Enosse would raise the chickls for 21 days and then sell them to slaughter houses. However, with the increase in the price of the feed, he decided to let go of that venture and keep his passengers transportation business only, which he achieved by using the vehicle he bought with severance reward. In 2004, he went back into the chicken raising business since prices were once again affordable. Nowadays, Enosse raises at least 400 chicks at a time. According to him the best results come from selling the chicken already slaughtered. He has been selling about 150 chickens every month to the Financial Department of the Namaacha District. The sale of live chickens is also lucrative. Enosse has generated a monthly income between MTN 3,000 and MTn 4,000 but he has not been able to save much due to high family expenses. This will be the second loan Enosse requests from Hluvuku and his fisrt through Kiva. With the first loan of MTn 7,000, Enosse purchased chicks and improved his business. This time, Enosse wants to apply the MTN 10,000 to purchase more chicks so that he can increase his flock and, therefore, profits. He will also fix the fencing which is old and need repairs. In the future Enosse wants to increase his chicken raising ability, purchase additional hens and buy a new vehicle to help transport and sell the chickens. His biggest dream, however, is to see his children graduate from college.

Translated from Portuguese by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

Enosse tem 41 anos de idade e é natural da província de Inhambane. Atualmente reside em Namaacha, uma vila na província de Maputo que faz fronteira com a Swazilandia. Enosse é casado e pai de 2 filhos, ambos estudantes sendo o maior com 13 anos e caçula com 10 anos de idade. Enosse vive na própria casa juntos com a sua esposa, seus filhos, um primo e uma sobrinha. Em 1987 saiu da província de Inhambane para Maputo a procura de emprego onde começa a trabalhar numa empresa que dois anos depois faliu. Assim seis meses depois houve outro empresário que decide abrir e chamar os antigos trabalhadores e ele foi um deles, já que não tinha arranjado ainda outro emprego. Este negocio também fechou 3 anos depois, mas desta vez indenizou os trabalhadores. Com o valor desta indenização Enosse comprou uma viatura e começou também com o negocio de criação de frangos de corte. Por quatro anos Enosse criava os frangos por 21 dias e vendia para outros criadores fazerem o abate. Porem, com a rápida elevação dos preços da ração, decide abandonar o negocio de criação de pintos e focar somente no transporte semi-coletivo de passageiro usando a viatura comprada pelo valor da indenização. Em 2004 decide voltar com a criação de frangos dado que os preços já estavam mais acessíveis. Enosse cria atualmente no mínimo 400 frangos de uma só vez. O melhor negocio segundo Enosse é vender já o frango abatido: tem vendido uns 150 frangos por mês para o Departamento de Finanças do Distrito de Namaacha. Porem a venda de frangos vivos também é lucrativa. Enosse tem tido um rendimento mensal entre MTn 3,000 e MTn 4,000 e não consegue poupar muito devido as despesas familiares. Este será o segundo empréstimo de Enosse com a Hluvuku, porem o primeiro com o Kiva. Com o primeiro empréstimo de MTn 7,000 Enosse comprou pintos e melhorou o seu negocio. Agora Enosse pretende usar os MTn 10,000 para novamente comprar pintos, aumentando a criação e os lucros. Assim conseguira reabilitar as capoeiras que já são antigas e precisam de reparos. No futuro Enosse gostaria de aumentar a sua criação de pintos, começar a criar poedeiras e comprar uma nova viatura para facilitar as vendas dos frangos. Seu maior sonho, porem, é ver um dia seus filhos formados na universidade.

loans.use: Purchase chicks for raising.

loans.name: Filéra

texts.fr:
Born in 1959 in Kabou in the Bassar prefecture, Mrs. Filéra B. is married and has two children. She is a courageous woman who sells firewood in Lomé. She has been doing this for more than 20 years and her main customers are bakers and local beverage producers. She buys wood wholesale or buys a tree trunk that she has cut up by lumberjacks. It is a very active business for her, but due to a lack of means, she is unable to meet customer demand. This is the second loan she has requested for this project, and she will use the money to buy 60 bundles of wood so she can satisfy her customers’ demands.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Née en 1959 à kabou dans la préfecture de Bassar, madame B. Filéra est mariée et a deux enfants. Elle est une femme vaillante qui exerce le commerce de vente de bois de chauffe à lomé. Elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 20 ans et a pour principaux clients les boulangers et les fabricants de boissons locales. Elle achète en gros ou achète un tronc d’arbre qu’elle fait scier par les spécialistes. C’est un commerce très florissant mais faute de moyens elle n’arrive pas à être à la hauteur de sa clientèle. A travers ce projet, elle sollicite ce second crédit pour acheter 60 fagots de bois afin de pouvoir satisfaire tous ses clients.

loans.use: Purchase of 60 bundles of wood

loans.name: Amela

texts.en:
Amela is from the town of Tesanj in northern Bosnia and Herzegovina. She is married and her husband works a full time job. Amela has started her own business in which she buys bedroom furnishings (including embroidered pillowcases, sheets, linens, and bedspreads) to then resell in and around her town. She is able to make about 400KM (US$305) a month through her sales.

With this 1200 KM (US$925) loan from Zene za Zene, Amela plans to order more inventory for her business. She hopes that she can buy some different types of linens this time, to have some more variety to offer her customers. She also hopes to earn more money by increasing the amount of items she sells monthly.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran S. A. is the wife of S. A. and lives in Kasur city, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its sweetmeat and historical places. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the last 40 years. She is the mother of six children: five sons and one daughter. Her eldest son handles power loom machines. Her second eldest son makes decoratively embroidered clothing. The other children are enrolled in a local neighborhood school. Sugran baji's husband has a musical band that plays at wedding functions. Sugran baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She is applying for a loan to buy a musical instrument for her husband's band.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Hamidan M. and Rani M. each want a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Bano B. wants a loan to buy materials (sharp razors, creams, etc.) for her barber shop. Parveen M. wants a loan to buy materials (beads, colored thread, sketches, etc.) for her decorative embroidery business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a musical instrument

loans.name: Njuambuh

texts.en:
Njuambuh M. is married to Alexander Kencholia and they have seven children, two of which are under the age of fifteen. She was born on June 5th, 1959; M. and her family live in a three-room house in the Nkwen neighborhood. 

As the family's bread-winner, Njuambuh finds it difficult to care for the family single-handedly. She was also in a serious accident involving getting robbed by thieves. Faced with a low level of education, she could not secure a good job for herself and thus started making and selling craft-work, something she has now been doing for fifteen years. She supplies the community with craft articles such as dulls.

When she became a member of GHAPE, she was fortunate to acquire some techniques which have helped her improve her craft business. She has had previous loans which she has successfully repaid. Njumbuh will use this loan for such craft supplies as fibers, straw, loin cloth, paint and camwood. She will repay this loan in 18 months, with repayments beginning four months from disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of craft supplies

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo J. C. is a member of community bank, Renacer, which in Spanish means, “rebirth”. Consuelo is married with 6 children that are all attending school. After preparing food in her house, Consuelo sells meals in the market in Ayacucho by the stadium.

She makes traditional and common meals including puca picante, which is a dish including potatoes, and a special sauce. When she is not preparing and selling food, she also sells dried goods at the fairs. With her loan of 1500 soles, she will invest into her business and purchase oatmeal, peas, corn, oil, potatoes and other dried goods. Consuelo is saving to improve her business and also to spend it on something secret.

loans.use: With her loan of 1500 soles, she will invest into her business and purchase oatmeal, peas, corn, oil, potatoes and other dried goods

loans.name: Umedjon

texts.en:
Umedjon M. is 36 years old. He learned his profession as a cattle farmer from his father when he was young. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and seeing his family progress more and more.

In addition to the animals, he also runs a taxi driving service in his free time. With his previous loans, he purchased two more cattle. He has already sold them and purchased two young calves, which he is rearing to sell. Today he wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. He is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD), which he's promising to repay within twelve months. From the profit of his business, Umedjon wants to be able to educate his children at the university in the future. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: To purchasing cattle and small cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Gribinet

texts.en:
Gribineţ T. is a 48-year-old woman who lives in the village of Carabetovca in the Basarabeasca district. She is in the agricultural industry, and she notes that her family has 2.64 hectares of agricultural land. She has been working this land since 2001. She has a relative who has some machinery to make working the land easier, but much of the work is manual labor. Thankfully, her 17-year-old daughter assists her with some such manual work, including weeding.

Next year she wants to plant 0.5 hectares of vines, so she is requesting a loan via Microinvest. Importantly, the land is ready for vines to be planted. This is the first loan that she has sought from Microinvest. With the loan proceeds, she would like to purchase grafts of the vines.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing vines to plant

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S., 39, is a widow and resides with two of her children in Siem Reap province. Since 2006, she has been selling grocery products to earn a living and is able to make around US$3 a day. Her two children are students. Mrs. S. would like to take out a loan of US $1000 to purchase groceries in bulk in order to receive a volume discount and also to meet her client’s demand.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk for resale

loans.name: Horun

texts.en: R. was born in 1985 and lives in Siem Reap Province. She runs a small store in front of her house. She sells groceries such as cooked ingredients, sweets, and boiled-eggs. Most of her customers are villagers. She married to Pheak, 28, who makes a living as a fisherman. The young couple has one young child who is a lovely baby. R. is asking for a loan to buy more products to sell and to buy a fishing net for her husband's business.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Arike

texts.en: Arike is 42 years old and she is married with 6 children. She sells sarongs, shoes, and cosmetics. She started this business in the year 2004. She hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more sarongs, shoes, and cosmetics to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs, shoes, and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
La señora Flor de Maria P. tiene 41 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de la Libertad.
Ella concluyo sus estudios secundarios, tiene 3 hijos que dependen económicamente de ella.
Flor tiene como negocio una pequeña tienda de abarrotes, al cual lo surte con mercadería como productos de belleza.
Con el crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Las Triunfadoras de Salaverry II”, lo invirtió en la compra de productos para surtir su tienda comercial, antes solo vendía abarrotes ahora también lo complementa con la venta de  útiles escolares, su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa. 
Con el crédito de 800 soles, que será cancelado en 6 meses, lo utilizará para comprar abarrotes al por mayor.   
Flor tiene como sueño hacer crecer su negocio con el apoyo de los créditos.
texts.en:
Flor de Maria P. is 41 years old and lives in Salaverry district, Trujillo province, La Libertad province. She has a high-school education and three children who depend on her economically. Flor owns a small grocery store, which she stocks with merchandise such as beauty products. With a loan of 300 soles she received through her communal bank, “Las Triunfadoras de Salaverry II”, she purchased products to supply her store; whereas before she only sold groceries, now she complements them with school supplies. Her business is located in her home. With this loan of 800 soles, which she will repay in six months, she will buy wholesale groceries. Flor hopes to expand her business with the support of these loans.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wholesale groceries

loans.name: Herlan

texts.es: Herland B. tiene 46 años de edad, recién se ha juntado con su concubina. Tiene 1 hijo de su primera novia, antes no se casó pero ahora ya tiene planes de boda con su actual cónyuge la cual no ha participado del crédito porque no tiene carnet de identidad. Herlan se dedica al transporte público de taxis, tiene su propio vehículo que lo conduce personalmente en el área urbana de Santa Cruz, tiene muchos años de experiencia en esta actividad. La competencia en el sector del transporte es alta pero también lo es la demanda por este servicio. El crédito fue destinado para la compra de la deuda o subrogación que tenia en su anterior crédito donde participaban 3 personas como codeudores y era él el único que cancelaba estas cuotas. Es un buen cliente con un excelente historial de pagos en la institución.
texts.en:
Herlan B. is 46 years old and recently moved in with his girlfriend. He has one son with his first girlfriend who he did not marry, but now he has wedding plans with his current girlfriend who has not been able to participate in the loans because she does not have an identity card. Herlan is in the business of public transport via taxis, he has his own vehicle which he personally drives in the urban area of Santa Cruz, and he has many years of experience in this activity. The competition in the transportation sector is high but there is also demand for the service.

The loan is destined for the payment of assumed debt that he has from a previous loan where three co-debtors participated and he was the only one who paid the debt. He is a good customer with an excellent payment history in the institution.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Payment of debt

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida T. is married with two children and has received an education through Vocational School. Since 1999, she has worked as a trader selling provisions at Ankwanda near Elmina.  Her husband is also a trader. Vida uses her income to pay for school fees, her family’s light bill and rent. She will use the loan to purchase additional provisions such as sugar, milk, rice and soap which she will sell in her shop. With the new profits from her expanded business, Vida plans to purchase land and build a home for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional provisions for her shop.

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.ru:
Дилбар Бурхонова женщина 49 лет. Проживает в городе Истаравшане вместе со своим мужем и 2 детьми. 
Дилбар занимается предпринимательской деятельностью, торгует на рынке сладостями.   Это печенье и конфеты. Дилбар арендует магазин, который находится возле хлебобулочного цеха, и стаж ее работы около 2 лет. 
С самого начала предпринимательской деятельности Дилбар  помогал сын, сейчас  она торгует на рынке сама.
Товар привозит с города Худжанда у оптовиков, и реализует  его в Истаравшане.
Наиболее прибыльными месяцами для реализации товара  это с мая месяца по январь месяц. 
Для реализации и товарооборота она запрашивает сумму 2000 сомони сроком на 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Dilbar B. is a 49 year old woman. She lives in the city of Istaravshan together with her husband and 2 children. Dilbar is an entrepreneur; she sells sweets at the market. This includes cookies and candy. Dilbar rents a store which is located next to a bread plant and she has around 2 years of experience. From the very start of her business, Dilbar’s son helped her, now she sells at the market herself She brings her products from the city of Khujand, from wholesalers and sells it in Istaravshan. Her most profitable months for selling products are from the month of May to the month of January. She is asking for a sum of 2000 somoni for sale and turnover.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For sales and turnover

loans.name: Djidja 2 .3 (Soyez Courageux). Group

texts.fr:
Djidja 2 .3 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village  Siguémona de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent  principalement  du riz et  de l’arachide comme activité Secondaire.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  Djidja 2 .3 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés  les trois  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter,  des semences de riz,  d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture,  au marché de Zansoni, M’pessoba et de Fonfona. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au  marché de M’pessoba et  de Koutiala, en détail ou en gros au comptant à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Djidja 2. 3 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 65 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Djidja 2 .3 is a group of married women of the village of Siguémona in Koutiala City, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large traditional extended families with their children, husbands, parents-in-law, sisters-in-law, etc. They have an average age of 35 and at least 6 children. They grow mainly rice, and they grown peanuts as a secondary business. Concerned about making their farms profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program four years ago. After having correctly repaid the three preceding loans, they are now on their fourth farm loan. The current loan will be used to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds for planting rice and peanuts, some minor supplies and equipment, and fertilizers and such, for farming. Supplies are gotten at the marketplaces of Zansoni, M’pessoba, and Fonfona. Following the off-season, the crops are stored for a certain time, so that they gain in value. Then the crops are sold retail and wholesale in cash transactions at the M’pessoba and Koutiala markets. Their customers come generally from large cities. After selling their produce, the group members each intend to realize a profit of 65,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan and to cover common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds, and minor supplies and equipment

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca T.' ultimate dream is to see all of her children graduate and succeed at whatever profession they take on. She is doing her best to make her farm productive, to finance the growing needs of her family. Rebecca is 37 years old and will do everything to look after her six children.

With her strong entrepreneurial spirit, she is asking for a loan from CEVI to finance her farm. She will use the loan to purchase two sacks of Urea, 30 liters of Crude oil and other farm needs. She thinks the loan will improve the yield of her crops. She expects to double her harvest this year. She was encouraged to join CEVI because it is not limited to loans. CEVI provides training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: Buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Karla María

texts.es: Doña Karla L.  cuenta con 30 años de edad, es Casada de oficios Comerciante, “Venta de alimentos” habita junto a su esposo y a sus 3 hijos, ella y su esposo se dedican al mismo oficio, lleva 6 años en el Servicio su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje Barranco Seco, Cantón Juchanep del departamento de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda de su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que el pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar más mercadería y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas por día, esperando también poder sacar adelante a sus hijos, y tener mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Karla L. is 30 and married. She sells food. She lives with her husband and their three children. She and her husband work at the same trade. She has been serving her community; which is in the Paraje Barranco Seco, Juchanep canton, Totonicapán department, Guatemala; for six years. Currently, customer demand has increased. But, her economic conditions are insufficient to increase her capital. That is why she has come to the Asociación ASDIR to ask for a loan. She intends to buy more merchandise and be able to increase her daily sales. She also hopes to be able to help her children get ahead and have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital(Food Sales)

loans.name: Leyce

texts.en:
Leyce is a member of the Tushikamane borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 33-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of two children. Her children are aged 12 and 5 years.

Leyce started her own business selling medicine three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 400,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Leyce’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 TSH in order to buy more medicine. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Leyce hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more medicine

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is a wife and mother of three children who are currently in school. She is forty seven year old trader who trades in charcoal. Charcoal is very popular source of energy for cooking in many traditional Ghanaian homes. Paulina obtains her supply of charcoal from kintapo a town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She supplies to food operators and retails them to other households in her community. She wants to use the loan to buy more supply of charcoal to increase her stock. She believes the loan will enable her increase savings to provide the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Gloria Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Gloria Del Carmen Gutiérrez  se dedica a la  elaboración de mochilas, las cuales vende ciertos lugares en los que tiene suficiente clientes. Hace más de 6 años de trabajar este negocio, sus hijos asisten a clase, Gloria ha luchado para sacar adelante su negocio por lo que tiene que proporcionarles a sus hijos estudios y alimentos. Ella disfruta mucho de su trabajo pues siempre recuerda que este el medio de vida que le genera los ingresos necesario del pan de cada día.  La señora está solicitando un nuevo financiamiento para la compra de materiales ya que tiene variedad de pedidos y necesita el crédito para cubrir la demanda. Su deseo es seguir con este negocio.
texts.en:
Señora Gloria Del Carmen Gutiérrez works making backpacks, which she sells in certain places where she has enough clients. She has done this work for more than 6 years. Her children are going to school. Gloria has fought in order to improve her business so that she can support her children’s studies and nutrition. She enjoys her work very much, and she always remembers that this is her way of getting the income needed for bread each day. Señora Gloria is asking for a new loan for the purchase of materials as she has a variety of orders and she needs the credit to meet the demand. Her dream is to continue with this business.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working funds

loans.name: Kanan

texts.en:
Kanan J. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phaste and is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes, cooking oil etc to sell. 

 Kanan is 26 years old and is Married with a husband that is a teacher. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for children

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase tomatoes, cooking oil etc to sell

loans.name: Ravshanbek

texts.en:
Cattle farming is an economic activity dedicated to the raising of animals in order to generate revenue from the animals and the products they provide. Ravshanbek has earned a living from raising cattle since he was young. He's married and has 5 children that, according to Ravshanbek’s words, are his reason for living. It should be said that the low incomes available to people in this rural aren't enough to maintain a family and for this reason, Ravshanbek works enormously hard to provide a better standard of living for his wife and children. Ravshanbek urgently needs to buy animals such as cows and calves. He's applied for a loan of $1700 USD. Be an important part of the growth of Ravshanbek’s business.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the young cattle

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet F. is 41 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a retail clothing business. While it is not Janet's only means of generating income, her clothing business is her main source of income. Janet has had her business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month. In 2009, Janet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the first Janet has taken out from HSPFI. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital.

location.town: Santa Felomena, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Srea

texts.en: Mrs. Srea L. was born in 1970. She lives in Trapaing Raing village in Takeo province. She is a breeder who raises pigs to earn her living. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. She decided to ask for a loan to buy 16 more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Loem Chantha, is a farmer. Mrs. Srea L. has five children, four of whom are attending the local school. Her youngest child is still too young to work or study. Her husband is in the photo, on the left.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy 16 piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en: Hiba is a 33-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has owned a lingerie shop since 2008 and she is the only provider for her family. She works hard to earn a good income to help satisfy their needs. Today, Hiba is asking for a loan of $1,200 to increase her inventory in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: Increase her inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To obtain more arable land

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia works on the farm for a living. She is 59 years old and resides in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She tends her farm for rice crops, which is one of the major agricultural crops in her province. Her income comes from farming alone. She hopes though that someday she would be able to expand her business or engage in another type of business.

Lilia is a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The main reason she joined the MFI is her inability to finance her business. She requested to loan PHP 7,000. She will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Chroeb C. is the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. She lives in Srae Vong Village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Vuth Soun, is shown on the left of the photo. He is farmer who is able to make a small income for his family.

Mrs. Chroeb C. is a grocer. She would like to improve and increase her income to support her family so she decided to ask for a loan from AMK to start a new business selling tamarinds (the pods of a tree, widely used as a flavoring in Asian cooking). She would like to use the rest of the loan to buy a motorbike to transport tamarinds to re-sell.

loans.use: To start a business selling tamarinds and to buy a motorbike to transport them

loans.name: Vilma's Group

texts.en:
Vilma B. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Vilma is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Vilma is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns and operates a business of selling dried fish and vegetables in the market. Aside from that, she also has a hog-raising business. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $88 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase some hog feed. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase some hog feed

loans.name: Suli Merly

texts.es:
Suli tiene 27 años de edad, es madre soltera  vive en casa propia con sus 2 hijas. ella inicio en el negocio de venta de ropa hace 2 años el cual comenzó con ahorros 
obtenidos por los mas de 4 años trabajando como obrera de campo en los fundos de la 
ciudad. Suli poco a poco ha ido incrementado su negocio y su clientela a los cuales 
les brinda precios bajos y prendas de calidad. Siendo muchos de sus clientes 
compañeros de sus centros de trabajo. Suli tiene el anhelo de construir su vivienda la 
cual fue seriamente afectada por el terremoto del 2007, y aún así siguen viviendo en esas 
condiciones. Además Suli quiere brindarles a sus hijas la mejor educación y una buena 
calidad de vida,ella requiere el crédito para la comprar de mercadería.
texts.en:
Suli is a 27 year old single mother who lives in her own home with her two daughters. She started a clothing business two years ago using the savings she built up after working more than four years as a farm worker on a large estate in the city. Over time, she increased her business and gained more customers by providing them low prices and quality clothing. Many of her customers are co-workers from the places where she was previously employed.

Suli dreams of rebuilding her house since it was seriously damaged by the earthquake of 2007, yet she still lives in it with its current condition. She wants to provide her children with the best education and a good quality of life, so she is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Ramota

texts.en:
Ramota is a beautiful and hardworking woman. She sells sarongs at retail prices to her customers and sells daily to make her business sustainable. Her customers A. usually friends and residents. She hopes to own a boutique in the future where she will sell only African fabrics.

Ramota hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is itching for business expansion.

Ramota is 58 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. Ramota duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Elsa Gioconda

texts.es: Elsa tiene varios financiamientos que le ha sido de gran ayuda para su negocio. Su negocio es una pulpería ubicada en la casa de habitación de su mama y de anteriormente trabajaba como profesora y por problemas de salud tomo la decisión de  establecer este negocio para brindar siempre ayuda a su hogar.  Su compañero de vida trabaja como técnico en refrigeración de manera ambulante por lo que juntos buscan la forma de generar más ingresos a sus familias. Es por eso que realiza este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de materia prima. Ella sueña con alcanzar muchos objetivos este año como es obtener su propia casa.
texts.en:
Elsa has had various loans, which have been a great help for her business. Her business is a general store located in her mother's home. Previously, she worked as a teacher, but for health reasons, she decided to start this business to provide a constant source of support for her household. Her life partner works as a mobile refrigeration technician, so that together they are trying to find ways to generate more income for their families. For this reason, she is requesting the current financing for working capital, which will be dedicated to buying supplies. Elsa dreams of achieving many goals this year, such as obtaining her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok S., age 47, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in the business of selling cakes and duck eggs at the rubber plantation, earning an income of USD 2.40 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver from his village to the market, earning an income of USD 3.30 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase a machine to produce animal food. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a machine to produce animal food

loans.name: Mrs. Saret Chay Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen people from Preaek Bak village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve living conditions for their families. Mrs. Saret C. is the village bank president who was selected by all the members. She and her husband, Mr. U. Luk, own a general store in the local village to earn money to support their family. Since their business is going well they want to expand it, but they did not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Saret C. has decided to seek a loan to buy more groceries for reselling. This couple has three children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory, while the other is a laborer.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for reselling.

loans.name: Luz Rene

texts.en:
Luz is married to Ronilo. They have three children; the oldest is 18 years old. Luz works in rice farming, and she currently owns three hectares of rice fields. She also has some pigs that she raises and sells. Luz works hard to help sustain her family. She hopes that all her children will finish college and find stable jobs.

Luz would like to request a loan of Php 15,000, which she will use to buy fertilizer and other farm necessities. She will also acquire feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy farm Supplies

loans.name: Parenda Group

texts.en:
Toryali is a member of Parenda group. He lives in district 1st of Kabul Afghanistan. He is a young boy of 25 and single, but still he feels lots of responsibility for his family members. He lives in a household of with five iother members: his father, mother and three sisters. 

He has an ice cream shop with lots of clients. He needs the loan to purchase good quality milk to make ice cream and to attract more new clients.

He is glad that he can progress through the loan and hopes to have a bright future.

loans.use: To buy more milk

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet S. is from the village of Parabba, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 42 years old. Juliet is married and has 7 young children. To make a living, Juliet owns & operates a business venture selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Juliet from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en:
Marie Chantal is 32 years old and married with five children who are between 2 and 11 years old. Marie Chantal is best known in the shoe selling business and this is her eighth successful year in this business. The hours of her business are from 7 am to 6 pm every day.

Marie Chantal is in the process of requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase different sizes of shoes (mainly women's shoes). With the additional stock, Marie will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business for better financial stability. In addition, Marie Chantal will improve the lifestyle of her work.

loans.use: To buy different styles of shoes to sell

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida lives in Anwerabad which is a small residential area in Vehari, Pakistan. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to expand his scrap business. She has two children, a son and a daughter. 

Khalida bibi loves her family, she wants to give her children  the best possible education, and she thinks that she can do it by expanding her husband’s business.

Note: In this picture, Khalida is showing her goat which she loves to take care of.

loans.use: Purchase scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en: Josephat is 31 years old, married and has a four-year-old son named Jonah. He makes a living by selling second-hand furniture while his wife earns an income by running a beauty a salon. Josephat has been in business for five years and now has one employee. Before he started his current business, he made a living selling second-hand clothes. Thanks to help from the Kamiti Road group in Faulu, Kenya, he has been able to expand his business by taking out a loan which he repaid on time. Now he is applying for a new loan, for 80,000 KES, to buy more furniture to sell to his customers. Josephat hopes to expand his business in the future so that he can improve his family's living standards. He also hopes to open a new wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy more furniture to selll to his customers

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.en:
Ronaldo P. is from the village of Doña Consuelo Ozamiz City. He is 43 years old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Ronaldo operates a tricycle transport "motorcab" services. Ronaldo has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ronaldo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 15000 PHP to repair his vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Ronaldo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle for better service

loans.name: Vy

texts.en:
Vy T. N. was born in 1958. She has a son, who works for a company near the house. Vy sells clothes in the market. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND.

She has participated in SEDA since 2007 and repaid punctually. She wants to expand her clothes shop, so she would like to borrow 8,502,000 VND.

loans.use: to expand her clothes shop

loans.name: Bayarjargal

texts.en: Bayarjargal G., a 41-year-old divorced woman, lives with her three children in their own ger (a traditional nomadic housing tent) in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city. Her middle daughter, Azzaya, attends a university and her youngest daughter studies at a secondary school. Her oldest, a son, works as a dancer for a government organization. Bayarjargal operates a retail clothing business. She began her business in 2003 and operates it out of a stall in Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar’s largest outdoor market. She imports new clothes from Erlian, a border city of China, and from Beejin, China's capital city, once a month. Her business is a popular spot in the market. Bayarjargal plans to expand her business by increasing her working capital for the peak season for sales. She hopes to renovate her house using her business earnings. Bayarjargal is requesting a 2,135,000 tugrik loan to buy more clothes and grow her working capital.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Medelyn

texts.en:
Medelyn V. is from the village of Barangay 5, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old, married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Medelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Medelyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Medelyn joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Medelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aireen

texts.en: Aireen L. is from the village of Bal-ason, Gingoog City. She is 31 years old. Aireen is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Aireen buys and sells coconuts in the local community. Aireen has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Aireen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aireen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional coconuts to sell. Aireen is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Aireen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Goma

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Goma D.. She is married and has three children who are 27, 23 and 20 years old. In 2005, she established her handicraft business. Working six days a week and five hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid four loans from Patan BPW, and used her most recent loan to purchase raw materials for her business.  

In the future, Goma plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.   

Nepal has a long and rich history of traditional handicrafts. Throughout the Kathmandu Valley, skilled artisans produce unique pieces of art that reflect Nepal's cultural diversity. Terra cotta pottery comes from the red clay of the surrounding Himalayan foothills. Bronze and silver statuettes are formed using wax molds and intricate hand tool finishing. In Patan, Newari culture and traditions are reflected in the images and symbols etched into metal or formed in stone. With the help of a Kiva loan, Nepal's artisans are able to purchase raw materials in greater volume. This increase in volume allows a single artisan to work on several pieces at the same time while increasing her profit margin. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her handicraft business

loans.name: Habiba Efua

texts.en: Habiba Efua I. lives with her husband and four children. She has been through junior high school. Habiba sells soft drinks in Asenadze near Abura. Her husband is a mason. She assists her husband with the upkeep of their home. She will use this loan to purchase new types of soft drinks to meet the demands of her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Habiba plans to build a shop.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks

loans.name: Gilberto Antonio

texts.es:
Gilberto es un joven de 21 años de edad, reside en Jiquilisco departamento de Usulután, es empleado de la agencia Alpina de Jiquilisco, el vive con su madre y sus hermanos, él es soltero, no tiene hijos; su madre vende refrescos en el mercado municipal de Jiquilisco.
Gilberto quiere ayudar a su madre para reparar el piso de su casa pero no cuenta con los fondos suficientes para comprar los materiales, él quiere encementar el piso ya que es de tierra y de esta manera estará más bonita y en mejores condiciones.
Su sueño es mejorar su casa poco a poco con esfuerzo y dedicación no duda en algún día lograrlo para cambiar así la apariencia del hogar y las condiciones actuales en las que viven.
texts.en:
Gilberto is a 21-year-old young man who lives in Jiquilisco, Usulután department.  He’s employed by Alpina (bottled water firm) in Jiquilisco.  He lives with his mother and siblings.  He’s single and doesn’t have any children.  His mother sells refreshments in the Jiquilisco Municipal Market.

Gilberto wants to help his mother repair the floor in their house but lacks enough funds to buy the materials.  He wants to lay a cement floor because it’s currently dirt.  This way it will be prettier and in better conditions.

His dream is to gradually, with effort and dedication, improve his home.  He doesn’t doubt that someday he will accomplish this to change its appearance and the current conditions they live in.

loans.use: To repair the floor in his house.

loans.name: Constance

texts.fr:
Cliente de 46 ans, mariée et mère de de 5 ans enfants,a commence la vente de la friperie en 2004, très enthousiaste en 2010, elle est octroyé pour un prêt de 250000frs et elle renforce son capital et achète tous ce dont ces clients ont besoin comme les serviettes, les body, les peignoirs et draps non utilises.
Ce prêt lui a rapportée beaucoup de bénéfices et elle a épargnée comme jamais elle l'a fait et a assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
Avec le second de prêt, elle compte renforcer encore son capital et agrandir le stock de ses  marchandises tel que les serviettes, peignoirs, draps  pour satisfaire aux besoins de sa clientèle. 
en tout cas elle tient a aller au bout de ses ambitions pour être une femme d'affaire de renommée
texts.en:
This customer, who is 46 years old, married and mother to five children, began selling second-hand clothing in 2004. She is still very enthusiastic about her business in 2010 and has already been granted a loan of 250,000 francs, with which she boosted her capital and bought everything her customers needed, such as towels, bodysuits, dressing gowns and non-used sheets. This loan brought in significant profits and she has saved like never before and also covered her children's schooling costs. 

With the second loan, she is planning to boost her capital even further and expand her stock of goods, such as towels, dressing gowns and sheets, in order to satisfy customer demand. In all cases she is determined to achieve her ambition to become a reputable businesswoman.

loans.use: Purchase of bundles of towels, dressing gowns and non-used sheets

loans.name: Serob

texts.en:
Serob A. lives in Yerevan. He is 26 years old and lives with his wife and his baby. From 2005 to 2008, Serob was a minibus driver. As his work wasn’t profitable, Serob decided to change his profession.  For about 2 years, Serob has engaged in jewelry production. 
Serob is a private entrepreneur renting a workshop and stall in one of the biggest jewelry markets in Yerevan.   He makes and sells his jewelry there. Thanks to the profit from his business, Serob can meet his young family's needs, and buy new furniture and household appliances for his apartment.
Serob asks for a $2500 loan to buy gold for his business because prices for gold are going up in gold markets now.  He hopes the loan will help him to increase his profit in future.

loans.use: To buy gold for his business

loans.name: Rita De Los Angeles

texts.es:
Rita de 28 años de edad, tiene una niña de 5 años, cuenta con la ayuda de su marido para los gastos familiares, el tiene su propio negocio de relojeria, ella trabaja como docente  desde hace 4 años en el colegio Cesar Augusto Salinas Pinell en la zona urbana de Nueva Guinea, es una joven  alegre, servicial y muy trabajadora, es bien querida por sus alumnos ya que siempre imparte sus clases con mucha dedicacaciòn y amor. 

Solicita nuevamente el apoyo de Kiva en su tercer  crèdito para invertirlo en reparacion de cocina la que gracias a este Financiador pudo constrirla, el cual ahora necesita mejorla y gozar  de buenas condiciones en el hogar.  

Su sueño en la vida es que su familia siempre permanezca en Uniòn y seguir estudiando para ser una profesional con mucho exito.
texts.en:
Rita is 28 years old and has a 5 year-old daughter.  She receives help from her husband in covering their family's expenses.  Her husband has his own watchmaking business.

Rita has been working as a teacher in Cesar Augusto Salinas Pinell School, in the urban area of Nueva Guinea for 4 years.  She is a happy, helpful and very hard-working young woman who is well liked by her pupils since she always gives her classes with a lot of dedication and love.

Rita is requesting Kiva's support again, with her third loan, as she would like to invest in repairing her kitchen which she was able to build thanks to her previous loans.  It now needs to be improved so that she can have her home in good condition.

Rita's dream in life is for her family to remain united and to continue studying so that she can be a very successful professional.

loans.use: To repair her kitchen

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun V., 28, is married and resides with her husband and one child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells palm fruit, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells palm sugar, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 43 on other necessary expenses. 

V. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Sao's Group

texts.en:
In Champuh K'aek village, in Kandal province, the members of this village bank loan selected Mrs. Sao K. as the president. The members hope to increase their income and improve the living standards of their families with these loans.

Mrs. Sao K. is a 35-year-old married woman. Her husband, Mr. Kang Kun, is 35 years old. He works as wedding chef to earn a little income to support his family. This couple has three children who are attending the local school.
  
Mrs. Sao K. earns her living by selling bananas and mangoes in the market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy more mangoes to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes to enlarge her business

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda T. is from the village of Seti, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Erlinda is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Erlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Huguet H

texts.es:
HUGUET A. E., ES DE MANAGUA, TRABAJA COMO PROFESORA,  ES MADRE DE FAMILIA DE TRES HIJOS Y DOS DE ELLOS ESTAN EN EL COLEGIO.
DOÑA HUGUET ACUDE A LAS OFICINAS DE CEPRODEL PARA SOLICITAR UN NUEVO PRESTAMO PARA EL MEJORAMIENTO DE SU VIVIENDA PARA INVERTIR EN LA COMPRA DE MATERIALES DE CONSTRUCCION COMO: CEMENTO, ARENA, PIEDRA Y PIEDRIN PARA TERMINAR DE CONSTRUIR UN CUARTO.
HUGUET DICE QUE GRACIAS A LOS FINANCIAMIENTOS OTORGADOS POR CEPRODEL HA VENIDO MEJORANDO SU CASA DE HABITACION Y A BRINDADO MEJORES CONDICIONES DE VIDA A SU FAMILIA.
texts.en:
Huguet A. E. is from Managua and works as a teacher.  She is the mother of 3 children, 2 of whom are in school.

Huguet came to the offices of CEPRODEL to request a new loan to make improvements to her house.  She wants to purchase construction materials such as: cement, sand, stones and gravel in order to complete the construction of a room.

Huguet says that thanks to the financings granted by CEPRODEL, she has been improving her home and providing better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to make improvements to her house.

loans.name: Sara

texts.es:
La señora Sara es socia del banco comunal Perlas de Pucallpa, del Distrito Calleria, Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 48 años de edad, es madre de 5 hijos.
Todos estos años desde que falleció su esposo tuvo que trabajar para poder criar a sus hijos, comenzó con el armado de un motocar que lo puso a trabajar, después de un tiempo reunió dinero para poder comprar un segundo motocar.
Con este nuevo préstamo de S/.3,000.00 nuevos soles comprará un motocar nuevo, con lo cual ya serian 3 motocar de su propiedad, su meta es tener 5 motocar a corto plazo, con eso ya tiene para poder mantener su pequeña flota de taxis.  Estos motocar están siendo trabajados por sus 2 hijos y su yerno.
Todavía tiene un hijo que está cursando estudios superiores y todo los gastos salen de las ferias (alquiler) que recibe de sus vehículos.

Sara agradece a Manuela Ramos por los prestamos que han hecho posible parte de sus sueños.
texts.en:
Sara is a member of the communal bank "Perlas de Pucallpa," in the Calleria district of the department of Ucayali. She is 48 years old and is the mother of 5 children.

During all the years since her husband died she had to work so that she could raise her children.  She started by assembling a motocar which she then put to work.  Then, over time, she gathered together enough money to buy a second motocar.  

With this new loan of 3,000 Peruvian soles, she will buy a new motocar, so that she will have a total of 3 vehicles.  Her goal is to have 5 motocars in the near term, and to be able to maintain her small fleet of taxis.  These motocars are being worked by her 2 sons and her son-in-law.

She has one son who is still taking college classes, and she covers all of the expenses with the rents that she receives from her vehicles.

Sara is grateful to the Manuela Ramos organization for the loans that have made part of her dream possible.

loans.use: to buy a new mototaxi

loans.name: Alba María

texts.es:
Alba María G. Q. es de origen campesino y desde pequeña ha aprendido las labores del campo para sobrevivir. Desde que se separó de su esposo Alba ha tenido que trabajar fuertemente pues aunque algunos de sus hijos trabajan no alcanza para cubrir los gastos de la numerosa familia conformada por 6 hijos. 

Es así como Alba actualmente necesita de un prestamos para completar el dinero que le hace falta para comprar una vaca y así producir leche para vender y obtener ingresos adicionales.
texts.en:
Alba María G. Q. has worked on farms her whole life and she depends on farming to survive.  She has had to work harder than ever since she split from her husband but her income--even with help from her children--doesn't stretch far enough to cover all the family's expenses.  Alba has a large family that includes 6 children.  

Alba needs a loan to make up the amount she needs to buy a cow for her milk business.

loans.use: to buy a cow for milk business

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily J. R. is 38 years old, married, and a mother of six children. They live in Waunifor in the outskirts of Eldoret. Emily is a maize farmer, and she sells the produce after harvest and has been in this business for eighteen years now. She gets a monthly income of thirty thousand shillings, and she also runs a retail shop in the same area, while her husband is also a maize farmer.

This will be Emily's third loan from KADET LTD. She repaid all other loans successfully, and she plans to use the entire loan on the farm by buying maize seedlings and fertilizer. With the income she is going to get from selling the maize, she wants to stock her shop with the money. In future she wants to educate her children to the highest level and also buy another piece of land.

loans.use: to buy maize, seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel B. is 40 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda.  He is married and has eight children.  Four of his children are currently in school.  Samuel has had a small retail shop for four years.         

To help expand his business, Samuel has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more essential commodities like sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Samuel hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, Samuel hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more essential commodities like sugar for resale.

loans.name: Las Nubecitas Group

texts.es:
La señora Bellarmina G. Gutiérrez, es casada con el señor  Audon Santos G. con quien procreo  dos hijas María de los Ángeles de siete años y Maira Jazmín de tan solo cuatro años quienes están en primaria y preescolar.

     Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de marranos y solicito el préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de alimentos, como son. Maíz, alimento, para que así  se críen como sus clientes  desean comprar, pues no los quieren flacos porque dice que no se vende si no están en buen calidad.

     Su actividad lo inicio hace dos años  onece meses  y es para apoyarse con los ingresos de su hogar aun que cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo ella también quiere aportar para así sacar adelante  a su peque familia.

     Ella  desea que con el préstamo y esta pequeña actividad pueda lograr incrementar mas su negocio  para que así logren sacar adelante a su tres hijas  si tres porque en unos días nace otra pequeña.

    Las personas que integran en el grupo son: Urema G. Gutiérrez, quien tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes y la señora Teresa  Gutiérrez Sánchez también en su pequeña tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Bellarmina G. Gutiérrez is married to Audon Santos G., and they have two daughters: María de los Ángeles, who is 7 and is in elementary school, and Maira Jazmín, who is only 4 years old and is in pre-school.

Bellarmina has a business raising and selling pigs.  She requests a loan to invest in the purchase of pig feed and corn so that they will grow into animals that her customers want to buy, as they don't like the skinny ones.  She says that the pigs don't sell if they are not good quality.

She started this business 11 years ago to help pay the household expenses.  Even though she has the support of her husband, she also wants to contribute to help her small family to get ahead.

With this loan, Bellarmina wants to expand her small business so that she can support her three children.  She says three, because very soon she will give birth to her third baby.

The members of this group are: Urema G. Gutiérrez, who has small grocery store, and Teresa  Gutiérrez Sánchez, who also has a grocery store.

loans.use: to buy pigs to raise and later sell, and also to buy feed and corn for them

loans.name: Wilikateme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Wilikateme, sont toutes des femmes mariées ont en moyenne 31 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Massoukou, sous préfecture de Fana; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font  le maraîchage, le commerce de charbon de bois et de condiments alimentaires.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Wilikateme sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du charbon et des condiments.  Le premier prêt a été remboursé sans aucune difficulté.                                                                       
SALIMATA compte acheter des 30 sacs charbon de bois avec les revendeurs du marché de Marka-Coungo. Elle effectue sa vente au village de Massoukou et au niveau du marché de Marka-Coungo, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt et le reste sera  investi dans son activité de maraîchage et cela le cadre de la diversification de ses activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Wilikateme group are all married and are on average 31 years old with 4 children.  They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Massoukou, in the Fana prefecture, Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
